item.title: Matteo Carandini
item.description: The journal eLife, which made the apparently brilliant decision to publish *before* peer review, actually "desk rejects" a whopping 73% of papers (including two of mine, erm, but never mind). So the gate-keeping is not gone but rather it has moved from the reviewers to... the editors. I think it was a mistake, especially for the journal who did so much to improve the review process by having reviewers consult each other. For more opinions, see this thread by Bevil Conway: https://twitter.com/BevilConway/status/1667877280880705536

item.title: Albert Cardona
item.description: @MatteoCarandini Conway is misrepresenting the data. The rate of desk reject is the same as before. If anything can be concluded is that unfortunately the rate hasn’t changed, as in, perhaps it would be good to accept more.The fear some senior editors had upon the introduction of the new publication model was that precisely desk reject would go up for fear of “pre-accepting” papers that upon peer review may turn out to be flawed. This has not materialised. So on this dimension the new model is a success. In every other dimension it’s the same as the old model, except authors now have more power. I am calling this a good outcome.Disclosure: I’m a senior editor at eLife.

item.title: JB Emmons
item.description: I've now seen multiple folks citing the 11th Circuit's 2006 decision in US v. Martin as grounds for arguing that Judge #Cannon can be forced to recuse in the #Trump documents prosecution.While I agree that Cannon 𝘴𝘩𝘰𝘶𝘭𝘥 recuse, for the reasons stated in Martin and elsewhere, I would caution against reading the case as 𝘳𝘦𝘲𝘶𝘪𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨 anything of the sort at this stage.The principle is one thing; getting to the point where the 11th Circuit will actually act on that principle is another.#LawFedi
